awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Elina Robeva is "The algebra and geometry of decomposing matrices, tensors and images." The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Pablo Parrilo.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
During my NSF postdoctoral fellowship, I worked on 7 projects, which resulted in 7 published articles:

[1] Geometry of Log-Concave Density Estimation Elina Robeva, Bernd Sturmfels and Caroline Uhler, Discrete and Computational Geometry, 2018

[2] Duality of Graphical Models and Tensor Networks Elina Robeva and Anna Seigal, Information and Inference: A Journal of the IMA, 2019

[3] Nested Covariance Determinants and Restricted Trek Separation in Gaussian Graphical Models Mathias Drton, Elina Robeva and Luca Weihs, Bernoulli, 2020

[4] Maximum Likelihood Estimation for Totally Positive Log-Concave Densities Elina Robeva Bernd Sturmfels, Ngoc Tran, and Caroline Uhler, Scandinavian Journal of Statistics, 2020

[5] Estimation of Monge Matrices Jan-Christian Huetter, Cheng Mao, Philippe Rigollet, and Elina Robeva, Bernoulli, 2020

[6] Optimal Rates for Estimation of Two-dimensional Totally Positive Distributions Jan-Christian Huetter, Cheng Mao, Philippe Rigollet, and Elina Robeva, Electronic Journal of Statistics, 2020

[7] Multi-trek Separation in Linear Structural Equation Models Elina Robeva and Jean-Baptiste Seby, SIAM Journal on Applied Algebra and Geometry (SIAGA), 2021

Articles [1], [4], [5], and [6] are all  concerned with statistical learning of totally positive distributions. Using total positivity was the first topic in my proposal, and  these articles are the result of my work in this direction.

Article [2] is concerned with tensor decompositions (the second topic in my proposal), and it shows a direct correspondence between tensor networks and graphical models.

Articles  [3], and [7] are concerned with hidden variable graphical models, whihch generalize the third topic in my original proposal. In these articles  we study structures that allow for causal inference in the presence of hidden variables.

Overall, I am quite satisfied with the outcome of my postdoctoral fellowship, and thrilled that I managed to find very good tenure-track job offers.



Last Modified: 12/29/2021
Modified by: Elina M Robeva

During my NSF postdoctoral fellowship, I worked on 7 projects, which resulted in 7 published articles:

[1] Geometry of Log-Concave Density Estimation Elina Robeva, Bernd Sturmfels and Caroline Uhler, Discrete and Computational Geometry, 2018

[2] Duality of Graphical Models and Tensor Networks Elina Robeva and Anna Seigal, Information and Inference: A Journal of the IMA, 2019

[3] Nested Covariance Determinants and Restricted Trek Separation in Gaussian Graphical Models Mathias Drton, Elina Robeva and Luca Weihs, Bernoulli, 2020

[4] Maximum Likelihood Estimation for Totally Positive Log-Concave Densities Elina Robeva Bernd Sturmfels, Ngoc Tran, and Caroline Uhler, Scandinavian Journal of Statistics, 2020

[6] Optimal Rates for Estimation of Two-dimensional Totally Positive Distributions Jan-Christian Huetter, Cheng Mao, Philippe Rigollet, and Elina Robeva, Electronic Journal of Statistics, 2020

[7] Multi-trek Separation in Linear Structural Equation Models Elina Robeva and Jean-Baptiste Seby, SIAM Journal on Applied Algebra and Geometry (SIAGA), 2021

Articles [1], [4], [5], and [6] are all  concerned with statistical learning of totally positive distributions. Using total positivity was the first topic in my proposal, and  these articles are the result of my work in this direction.

Article [2] is concerned with tensor decompositions (the second topic in my proposal), and it shows a direct correspondence between tensor networks and graphical models.

Articles  [3], and [7] are concerned with hidden variable graphical models, whihch generalize the third topic in my original proposal. In these articles  we study structures that allow for causal inference in the presence of hidden variables.

Overall, I am quite satisfied with the outcome of my postdoctoral fellowship, and thrilled that I managed to find very good tenure-track job offers.
